heading.title: DIVISION 2 PROVISIONS APPLICABLE TO EXPERT EVIDENCE GENERALLY [rr 31.17–31.54]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: DIVISION 2 PROVISIONS APPLICABLE TO EXPERT EVIDENCE GENERALLY [rr 31.17–31.54]
[r 31.19] r 31.19 Parties to seek directions before calling expert witnesses

leg:heading.title: Parties to seek directions before calling expert witnesses

p.text: Any party:
intending to adduce expert evidence at trial, or
to whom it becomes apparent that he or she, or any other party, may adduce expert evidence at trial,
must promptly seek directions from the court in that regard.

Directions under this rule may be sought at any directions hearing or case management conference or, if no such hearing or conference has been fixed or is imminent, by notice of motion or pursuant to liberty to restore.
Unless the court otherwise orders, expert evidence may not be adduced at trial:
unless directions have been sought in accordance with this rule, and
if any such directions have been given by the court, otherwise than in accordance with those directions.
This rule does not apply to proceedings with respect to a professional negligence claim.
[subr (4) insrt Gaz 87 of 6 July 2007 r 2 and Sch 1[5], effective 6 July 2007]

heading.title: Prior directions — precondition to the use of expert evidence

p.text: This rule effectively conditions the use of expert evidence on compliance with the court’s prior directions. The rule partly adopts the recommendation made in the NSWLRC Report 109 Expert Witnesses (New South Wales Law Reform Commission, Sydney, 2005). It parallels similar rules in other jurisdictions (eg England, Queensland and the Family Court). The rule requires parties to apply promptly for directions. The requirement for promptness is intended to ensure the court is able to exercise its case management powers at an appropriately early stage of the proceedings. Directions under the present rule may be sought either at a directions hearing or case management conference or by notice of motion.

The restriction on the use of expert evidence only applies to evidence to be given at trials (ie, any non interlocutory hearing – see CPA s 3 ): Stolfa v Owners Strata Plan 4366 (No 2) [2008] NSWSC 531; BC200804137 at [2]Â . Consequently prior directions are not required to adduce expert evidence in applications under UCPR r 2.1 (directions) UCPR r 25.2 (interim relief) or UCPR r 42.21 (security for costs) — to give a few, non-exhaustive examples of interlocutory hearings. However, the dichotomy between trial and interlocutory hearings assumes a distinction that is not always easy to draw — as the examples discussed in [SCA s 101.75] –[SCA s 101.82] show. No doubt the practical resolution of any difficulties to which the distinction might give rise will lie in resort to the courts’ general powers under UCPR r 2.1 (which will permit expert evidence directions to be made even in relation to interlocutory hearings) or either CPA s 14 (which permits the courts to dispense with the requirements of the rules in an appropriate case) or the similar dispensation expressed in UCPR r 31.19(3) .

Professional negligence claims , as defined in the Dictionary, include claims against medical and related health practitioners and service providers and legal practitioners. In proceedings of these kinds (other than proceedings against a legal practitioner and unless the court otherwise orders) the plaintiff must serve an expert’s report with the statement of claim commencing the proceedings: see UCPR r 31.36 .

heading.title: Discretion to withhold directions for the use of expert evidence

p.text: The purpose of the requirement for direction is to restrict the use of expert evidence to that which is reasonably required having regard to the overriding purpose of facilitating the fair, just and economical resolution of the proceedings: see CPA ssÂ 56–60 : eg Countouris v Kallos [2007] NSWSC 944; BC200707107 at [5]Â per Young CJ in Eq (an application for expert handwriting evidence was postponed to ascertain whether the maker of a disputed proxy was available to give evidence).
Directions permitting the use of expert evidence will be withheld where the court is not satisfied that the proposed expert evidence:

is reasonably required to resolve the issues in the proceedings: Chapman v Chapman [2007] NSWSC 1109; BC200708531Â (expert accountancy evidence refused in proceedings to rectify will — evidence proposed to address possible meaning of expressions used in the will);

does relate to a real issue in the proceeding: Bizzanelli v Bizzanelli [2007] NSWSC 1085; BC200708672Â (no tenable basis for discretionary defence to proceedings under sÂ 66G of the Conveyancing Act (NSW) 1919 — leave to adduce expert accounting evidence refused).

level.toc-caption: [31.19.20] Expert evidence directions in the Supreme Court Equity Division

heading.title: Expert evidence directions in the Supreme Court Equity Division

p.text: Practice note SC Eq 5 applies to expert evidence in proceedings in the Equity Division of the Supreme Court. The Practice Note requires legal representatives to confer with a view to formulating an agreed procedure in relation to expert evidence. Where the parties reach agreement the court may make any required directions in the absence of the parties provided they file a signed “Request for Expert Evidence Directions” complying with Annexure A to the Practice Note: see Practice note SC Eq 5 para 13. If the parties are unable to achieve agreement, appropriate directions can be sought in the manner stipulated in para 15 of Practice note SC Eq 5.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 31.20] r 31.20 Court may give directions regarding expert witnesses

leg:heading.title: Court may give directions regarding expert witnesses

p.text: Without limiting its other powers to give directions, the court may at any time give such directions as it considers appropriate in relation to the use of expert evidence in proceedings.
Directions under this rule may include any of the following:
a direction as to the time for service of experts’ reports,
a direction that expert evidence may not be adduced on a specified issue,
a direction that expert evidence may not be adduced on a specified issue except by leave of the court,
a direction that expert evidence may be adduced on specified issues only,
a direction limiting the number of expert witnesses who may be called to give evidence on a specified issue,
a direction providing for the engagement and instruction of a parties’ single expert in relation to a specified issue,
a direction providing for the appointment and instruction of a court-appointed expert in relation to a specified issue,
a direction requiring experts in relation to the same issue to confer, either before or after preparing experts’ reports in relation to a specified issue,
any other direction that may assist an expert in the exercise of the expert’s functions,
a direction that an expert who has prepared more than one expert’s report in relation to any proceedings is to prepare a single report that reflects his or her evidence in chief.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 31.21] r 31.21 Expert evidence in chief to be given by way of experts’ reports

leg:heading.title: Expert evidence in chief to be given by way of experts’ reports

p.text: Unless the court otherwise orders, an expert witness’s evidence in chief must be given by the tender of one or more expert’s reports.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 31.22] r 31.22 Expert witness to provide details of contingency fees or deferred payment schemes

leg:heading.title: Expert witness to provide details of contingency fees or deferred payment schemes

p.text: A person who is engaged as an expert witness in relation to any proceedings must include information as to any arrangements under which:
the charging of fees or costs by the expert witness is contingent on the outcome of the proceedings, or
the payment of any fees or costs to the expert witness is to be deferred,
in, or in an annexure to, any report that he or she prepares for the purposes of the proceedings.
If a report referred to in subrule (1) indicates the existence of any such arrangements, the court may direct disclosure of the terms of the engagement (including as to fees and costs).

The rule requires an expert to disclose any special arrangement under which payment of their fees has been deferred or is contingent upon the outcome of the proceedings. The rule gives effect to the recommendation of the NSW LRC Report 109 Expert Witnesses, (New South Wales Law Reform Commission, Sydney, 2005) Â¶9.20-9.41. The Commission considered that special fee arrangements of this kind were relevant to the potential existence of what it described as "adversarial bias". The disclosure requirement is intended to reduce the potential risk of such bias by requiring candid disclosure and, in an appropriate case, permitting further enquiry about the nature and effects of the details of any special funding arrangement. (The NSW LRC Report 109 in Â¶5.5 & 5.10 usefully discusses various elements of the partiality perceived to be associated with expert evidence. The report distinguished between: (i) preconceptions, (ii) partisanship, (iii) adversarial bias, and (iv) selection bias).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 31.23] r 31.23 Code of conduct (cf SCR PartÂ 39, ruleÂ 2; DCR PartÂ 28A, ruleÂ 2; LCR PartÂ 38B, ruleÂ 2)

leg:heading.title: Code of conduct (cf SCR PartÂ 39, ruleÂ 2; DCR PartÂ 28A, ruleÂ 2; LCR PartÂ 38B, ruleÂ 2)

p.text: An expert witness must comply with the code of conduct set out in ScheduleÂ 7 .
As soon as practicable after an expert witness is engaged or appointed:
in the case of an expert witness engaged by one or more parties, the engaging parties, or one of them as they may agree, or
in the case of an expert witness appointed by the court, such of the affected parties as the court may direct,
must provide the expert witness with a copy of the code of conduct.

Unless the court otherwise orders, an expert’s report may not be admitted in evidence unless the report contains an acknowledgment by the expert witness by whom it was prepared that he or she has read the code of conduct and agrees to be bound by it.

Unless the court otherwise orders, oral evidence may not be received from an expert witness unless the court is satisfied that the expert witness has acknowledged, whether in an expert’s report prepared in relation to the proceedings or otherwise in relation to the proceedings, that he or she has read the code of conduct and agrees to be bound by it.

The Sch 7 expert witness code of conduct governs the form of an expert’s report and specifies an expert witness’s obligation to comply with any direction to confer or produce a joint report (see NSW LRC Report 109 Expert Witnesses, (New South Wales Law Reform Commission, Sydney, 2005) Â¶3.9). The provisions of the expert witness code of conduct have been strongly influenced by the common law, including the principle that expert evidence presented to the court should be, and should be seen to be, the independent product of the expert uninfluenced by the exigencies of litigation: see National Justice Compania Naviera SA v Prudential Assurance Co Ltd (The Ikarian Reefer) [1993] 2 Lloyd’s Rep 68 (the passage cited summarises the position under the general law); and see further [31.29.10] . The expert witness code provisions are not intended to operate directly as rules of admissibility. Their primary intention is to operate as a code of conduct designed to improve the quality of expert evidence: Australian Securities and Investments Commission v Rich (2005) 190 FLR 242; 53 ACSR 110; [2005] NSWSC 149; BC200501057 at [333]Â (see NSW LRC Report 109 Â¶3.10].

level.toc-caption: [31.23.7] Independence of expert witness — Land and Environment Court

heading.title: Independence of expert witness — Land and Environment Court

p.text: Council staff and employees, such as development planners, have been held to lack independence in relation to expert reports they may prepare for council. They are likely to be excluded from being expert witnesses in matters involving their employers in the Land and Environment Court: Willoughby City Council v Transport Infrastructure Development Corp (No 2) [2008] NSWLEC 238; BC200805801Â (report prepared by council’s employee development planner excluded because expert witness was not independent from the party and from the matter in dispute).

(CTH) Evidence Act 1995 sÂ 69.

An expert witness's evidence, whether oral or written, is not admissible in the absence of an acknowledgement of the code of conduct — unless the court otherwise orders. The court should not “otherwise order” unless it is satisfied there are good reasons to admit the evidence. But it is not necessary to show “exceptional circumstances”: Hodder Rook & Associates Pty Ltd vÂ Genworth Financial Mortgage Insurance Pty Ltd [2011] NSWCA 279; BC201107141Â atÂ [56]–[62] (subsequent (but out of time) reports contained acknowledgment — no prompt objection by other party — no requirement for “exceptional circumstances”).

The discretion may be appropriately exercised where the court is satisfied that non-compliance with the acknowledgment requirement was “technical” in the sense that the report was in fact prepared in compliance with the code: Barak Pty Ltd v WTH Pty Ltd (t/as Avis Australia) [2002] NSWSC 649; BC200204086Â ; contrast Commonwealth Development Bank of Australia Pty Ltd vÂ Cassegrain [2002] NSWSC 980; BC200206442Â (witness unaware of the code when report prepared). Similarly, it may be appropriate to exercise the discretion where the expert witness sufficiently confirmed the report after being apprised of the contents of the code: Langbourne v State Rail Authority [2003] NSWSC 537; BC200303211Â ; Jermen v Shell Co of Australia Ltd [2003] NSWSC 1106; BC200307299Â . It may also be appropriate to exercise the discretion where the court is otherwise satisfied of the likely impartiality of the opinions expressed in an expert witness report: United Rural Enterpriese Pty Ltd v Lopmand Pty Ltd [2003] NSWSC 870; BC200305685Â .

The discretion should not be exercised (even where the expert has subsequently been provided with and read and agreed to be bound by the Expert Witness Code of Conduct) if it is apparent that witness has not clearly displayed any real understanding of and compliance with the substance of the expert witness code: Re Idylic Solutions Pty Ltd [2012] NSWSC 731; BC201204805 atÂ [16]Â ff esp atÂ [58] and [61] (facts, assumptions and reasoning not clearly set out); Welker vÂ Rinehart (NoÂ 6) [2012] NSWSC 160; BC201201270 atÂ [36]Â (appearance of partisanship from the contents of the report).

Even if the literal wording of UCPR rÂ 31.23(3) does not require an “expert report” (that is one that was not prepared for the purpose of the proceedings and was potentially admissible as a business record under Evidence ActÂ 1995 sÂ 69 ) to contain a code acknowledgement, the court could exclude the report if it was satisfied that the report might be misleading, confusing or unfairly prejudicial to a party: Investmentsource Corp Pty Ltd vÂ Knox Street Apartments Pty Ltd [2007] NSWSC 1128; BC200708776 atÂ [46]Â .

level.toc-caption: [31.23.15] The liability of expert witnesses — damages

heading.title: The liability of expert witnesses — damages

p.text: The general rule is that witnesses, like judicial officers and advocates, have an absolute immunity from suit in respect of their evidence: Jamieson v R (1993) 177 CLR 574 at 582–3Â , 589; Gibbons v Duffell (1932) 47 CLR 520 at 525; BC3200029Â . That immunity extends to the contents of out of court witness statements made for the purpose of the proceedings: Mann v O’Neill (1997) 191 CLR 204; BC9703256Â ; Watson v McEwan [1905] AC 480Â ; Taylor v Director, Serious Fraud Office [1999] 2 AC 177Â . It applies even in relation to claims that witnesses conspired to give false evidence: Cabasi v Vila (1940) 64 CLR 130; BC4100010Â ; but see Darker v Chief Constable of the West Midlands Police [2001] 1 AC 435Â . Notwithstanding the scope of the immunity, an expert retained by a party is likely to owe that party a duty to exercise reasonable care and skill. Breach of that duty to advise is actionable notwithstanding the general immunity: Palmer v Durnford Ford [1992] QB 483; [1992] All ER 122Â . The distinction between an expert witness’s private contractual obligations and their functions as an independent expert may be difficult to draw: Evans v London Hospital Medical College (University of London) [1981] 1 WLR 184Â (pathologist communicating post mortem results to prosecutor — immunity); XÂ (Minors) v Bedforshire County Council [1995] 2 AC 633 at 755Â (psychiatrist reporting to council on alleged sexual abuse — immunity). The distinction contemplated is similar to that between the curial conduct of advocates (to which immunity applies) and their conduct as advisers (to which the immunity does not extend): see Boland v Yates Property Corporation Pty Ltd (1999) 167 ALR 575; BC9908012 at [97]Â and [360]–[365]. In Stanton v Callaghan [2000] 1 QB 75 at 98Â and 100 Chadwick LJ suggested that drawing the distinction in any particular case involved a factual enquiry as to whether the relevant conduct of the expert was in fact principally related to either advising the client or preparing their evidence. Otton LJ suggested the relevant criterion was whether the particular conduct was “principally and proximately” connected with the preparation of the expert’s evidence, QB at 104). However the precise distinction is expressed, it is clear that no action will lie against an expert for lack of care in relation to the content of the evidence they give, including the content of advice prepared with, or after consultation with, another expert engaged for the purpose of the proceedings: Stanton v Callaghan [2000] 1 QB 75Â (engineering expert).

level.toc-caption: [31.23.20] The liability of expert witnesses — costs

p.text: Legislation cited in [31.23.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.

heading.title: The liability of expert witnesses — costs

p.text: UCPR r 31.23 imposes on an expert witness a mandatory obligation to comply with the Schedule 7 Code of Conduct and to agree to be bound by its obligations. An expert who complies with those requirements, because of the content of para 2 of Sch 7, voluntarily assumes an “overriding” and “paramount” duty to assist the court impartially and, in particular, to identify any opinions they regard as incomplete, inconclusive or inaccurate: see Sch 7 para 5 . Similarly worded obligations under the English Civil Procedure rules have been held to permit the court to impose costs sanctions in the case of an expert witness’s reckless or flagrant disregard of their obligations — notwithstanding the general immunity of witnesses in proceedings: see Phillips v Symes (No 2) [2005] 4 All ER 519 at 543Â (psychiatrist — reckless disregard of duties — significant costs). The rules would appear to provide no clear basis for applying a costs sanction to an expert witness.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 31.24] r 31.24 Conference between expert witnesses (cf SCR PartÂ 36, ruleÂ 13CA; DCR PartÂ 28, ruleÂ 9D; LCR PartÂ 23, ruleÂ 1E)

leg:heading.title: Conference between expert witnesses (cf SCR PartÂ 36, ruleÂ 13CA; DCR PartÂ 28, ruleÂ 9D; LCR PartÂ 23, ruleÂ 1E)

p.text: The court may direct expert witnesses:
to confer, either generally or in relation to specified matters, and
to endeavour to reach agreement on any matters in issue, and
to prepare a joint report, specifying matters agreed and matters not agreed and reasons for any disagreement, and
to base any joint report on specified facts or assumptions of fact,
and may do so at any time, whether before or after the expert witnesses have furnished their experts’ reports.
The court may direct that a conference be held:
with or without the attendance of the parties affected or their legal representatives, or
with or without the attendance of the parties affected or their legal representatives, at the option of the parties, or
with or without the attendance of a facilitator (that is, a person who is independent of the parties and who may or may not be an expert in relation to the matters in issue).
An expert witness so directed may apply to the court for further directions to assist the expert witness in the performance of his or her functions in any respect.
Any such application must be made by sending a written request for directions to the court, specifying the matter in relation to which directions are sought.
An expert witness who makes such an application must send a copy of the request to the other expert witnesses and to the parties affected.
Unless the parties affected agree, the content of the conference between the expert witnesses must not be referred to at any hearing.

heading.title: Expert witness — application for directions by

p.text: Perceived bias does not generally operate as a bar to the admissibility of an expert report: see [31.29.25] & Australian Securities and Investments Commission v Rich (2005) 190 FLR 242; 53 ACSR 110; [2005] NSWSC 149; BC200501057 at [334]Â . But both the rules and general principle require an expert witness to approach their task on the basis that they have coincident duties to the court, and the party retaining them, to give properly informed and objective evidence based upon a specialised knowledge. In the case of any perceived conflict between the client interest and the expert's duty, the expert has an overriding duty to assist the court impartially on matters relevant to the expert’s area of expertise: see UCPR Sch 7 cl 2 . And the rules require the expert to acknowledge the force of that obligation. An expert who is directed to hold conferences with other experts may apply to the court for further directions. The court may direct that the conference be held with or without the attendance of lawyers. The content of the conference between the expert witnesses cannot be referred to at the hearing or trial unless the parties agree. Where expert witnesses have conferred and have provided a joint report agreeing on any matter, a party affected may not, without the leave of the court, adduce expert evidence inconsistent with the matter agreed: see UCPR r 31.26 .
Legislation cited in [31.24.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.

(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 31.24(2)(a).

The procedure for joint conferences in proceedings in the Supreme Court is dealt with in Practice Note SC Gen 11 , and provides a useful guide for the procedure to be applied in other courts. The Practice Note deals with:
the questions and materials to be provided to the experts;
the conduct of the conference;
the provision of a joint report; and
the role of legal representatives in relation to the joint conference.

In exercising the discretion to direct a meeting of experts, it is proper to consider the extent to which the meeting is reasonably likely to narrow issues, reduce the scope of evidence and resolve differences of expert opinion (ie, satisfy the various objectives identified in the Practice Note): Booth v Di Francesco [2002] NSWSC 154; BC200200722 at [24]Â (considered divergence of expert views, critical underlying factual assumptions, court not satisfied of “possible utility”, order refused); Spasovic v Sydney Adventist Hospital [2002] NSWSC 164; BC200200855Â (divergent medical opinion, contentious relevant history, order refused); Boardman v South Eastern Sydney Area Health Service [2001] NSWSC 930; BC200106490Â (multiple experts, difficulty arranging face to face meeting, widely stated issues, order refused); Habelrih v Szirt [2004] NSWSC 54; BC200400429 at [12] and [26]Â (incompletely expressed opinions, conference ordered). In addition, the court will consider the costs of the meeting, and its potential impact on the parties, including any risk that extra costs (including preparation and expert’s fees) may prejudice a party’s ability to conduct the proceedings effectively and at the least cost: Guerin v Watts [2002] NSWSC 692; BC200204398Â .

The court may direct a conference be held “with or without the attendance of the parties affected”: UCPR r 31.24(2)(a) . But because the basis of expert opinion, and the material on which it relies, should always be apparent from the report, it is good practice to ensure that the experts are properly instructed and directed about the matters they should consider, and the procedure they should follow, at such a conference. Nevertheless, a failure to comply with such a practice does not necessarily vitiate the result: Chaina v Alvaro Homes Pty Ltd [2008] NSWCA 353; BC200811259 at [69]–[70]Â per Basten JA (a complaint was made that information was supplied to the experts informally in circumstances which had not been agreed in advance and was not consented to by the lawyers for the appellants).

The rules relating to joint conferences between expert witnesses are complemented by the further rules in UCPR rÂ 31.35 that permit the court to give particular directions about the stage of the proceedings when expert evidence is given, requiring an expert to take into account particular aspects of the evidence, and requiring relevant expert witnesses to be present, and give their evidence, concurrently: see Â [31.35.5].

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 31.25] r 31.25 Instructions to expert witnesses where conference ordered before report furnished

leg:heading.title: Instructions to expert witnesses where conference ordered before report furnished

p.text: If a direction to confer is given under ruleÂ 31.24(1)(a) before the expert witnesses have furnished their reports, the court may give directions as to:
the issues to be dealt with in a joint report by the expert witnesses, and
the facts, and assumptions of fact, on which the report is to be based,
including a direction that the parties affected must endeavour to agree on the instructions to be provided to the expert witnesses.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 31.26] r 31.26 Joint report arising from conference between expert witnesses (cf SCR PartÂ 36, ruleÂ 13CA; DCR PartÂ 28, ruleÂ 9D; LCR PartÂ 23, ruleÂ 1E)

leg:heading.title: Joint report arising from conference between expert witnesses (cf SCR PartÂ 36, ruleÂ 13CA; DCR PartÂ 28, ruleÂ 9D; LCR PartÂ 23, ruleÂ 1E)

p.text: This rule applies if expert witnesses prepare a joint report as referred to in ruleÂ 31.24(1)(c) .
The joint report must specify matters agreed and matters not agreed and the reasons for any disagreement.
The joint report may be tendered at the trial as evidence of any matters agreed.
In relation to any matters not agreed, the joint report may be used or tendered at the trial only in accordance with the rules of evidence and the practices of the court.
Except by leave of the court, a party affected may not adduce evidence from any other expert witness on the issues dealt with in the joint report.

Although a party cannot adduce additional expert evidence without leave, proper exercise of the discretion to grant leave only requires satisfaction there is an appropriate basis to permit a party to adduce additional evidence: Proper basis may exist where the issues addressed by the expert involve particular complexity: Tabet (by her tutor Sheiban) v Mansour [2006] NSWSC 754; BC200605691Â (complexity of medical issues — leave granted conditional on calling a particular doctor who had attended the joint conference of experts): see further [31.44.5] .

The present rule only requires the joint expert report to specify reasons for any matters of disagreement in the report. Nevertheless, the rule also explicitly permits the tender of the report, as to the matters agreed. And the rule appears to draw a distinction, in this respect, between matters on which the experts agree, and those on which they disagree. In the latter case, the joint report is only available for use at the trial “in accordance with the rules of evidence and the practices of the court”. The rule probably assumes that the experts statement of agreement is in fact a conclusion based on specialised knowledge, for the purposes of sÂ 79 of the Evidence Act, and for that reason dispenses with any additional requirement that their reasoning process be expressly articulated in the joint report: X v Sydney Children’s Hospitals Specialty Network (NoÂ 5) [2011] NSWSC 1351; BC201108817Â atÂ [32]–[50]; Gillett v Robinson [2011] NSWSC 1143; BC201107572Â atÂ [45]. The rule is however merely permissive and does not require the admission of joint expert reports, if the court is not satisfied that the opinions expressed in them are in substance opinions based on specialised knowledge, or otherwise soundly based: Barescape Pty Ltd v Bacchus Holdings Pty Ltd [2011] NSWSC 1002; BC201106613Â atÂ [3]–[5] per BlackÂ J.
